conclusion: Block C moves with an initial velocity v0.
Block B is initially at rest.
The distance traveled by block C before the collision is s0.
The kinetic energy of block C before the collision is (1/2) m v0^2.
The work done by friction over distance s0 is μ m g s0.
Using energy conservation, (1/2) m v1^2 = (1/2) m v0^2 - μ m g s0.
Solving for v1 gives v1 = sqrt(v0^2 - 2 μ g s0).
The collision is perfectly inelastic, so blocks B and C stick together.
Initial momentum before collision is m v1.
Final combined mass after collision is 2m.
Final momentum after collision is 2m v2.
Using momentum conservation, m v1 = 2m v2.
Solving for v2 gives v2 = v1/2 = sqrt(v0^2 - 2 μ g s0)/2.
Initial kinetic energy before the collision is (1/2) m v1^2.
Final kinetic energy after the collision is (1/2) (2m) v2^2 = m (v1/2)^2 = (1/2) m (v1^2/4).
Mechanical energy loss ΔE is (1/2) m v1^2 - (1/2) m (v1^2/4).
Simplifying gives ΔE = (1/2) m v1^2 (1 - 1/4) = (3/8) m v1^2.
Substituting v1 gives ΔE = (3/8) m (v0^2 - 2 μ g s0).
The mechanical energy loss during the collision is ΔE = (3/8) m (v0^2 - 2 μ g s0).
